Message.Title: No More Excuses
Message.Msg: With the light at the end of the litigation tunnel growing brighter, BAC management will have to prove themselves on business fundamentals. They won't be able to use the legal problems as an excuse to muck up the numbers. If they are, and I suspect they are, then stockholders will see a lot more plus from the stock price, dividends, and buybacks in the future.

Topic.Title: FED is fueling a stock market bubble that will surely explode!

Message.Msg: Actually, the Fed is fueling corporate profits which have nearly doubled in the past 4 years. Market is at 15 times this year's eps. Hardly a bubble. In 1999-2000 the market was at 32 times eps. That's a bubble. The real long term problem here is Fed QE policy is shifting bad debt from the private sector to the public sector. Who's going to bail out the public sector????

Message.Title: Bank of America Corp. (BAC) said New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has no right to take enforcement action against the bank over claims that it violated terms of a nationwide foreclosure settlement.
Message.Msg: BAC is doing like BP with Macondo Mess or (Mortage mess) it's Halliburton & RIG fault??? Bank of America Corp. (BAC) said New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has no right to take enforcement action against the bank over claims that it violated terms of a nationwide foreclosure settlement. The settlement permits enforcement actions when a bank fails to comply with defined metrics and an opportunity to “cure” the violation has been provided, the bank said in a May 7 letter to Schneiderman. The bank says it has complied with “every applicable metric.” “Your office has no right under the express terms of the national mortgage settlement to commence an enforcement action against Bank of America, and we respectfully request that your notice of intent to do so be publicly withdrawn,” attorneys for the bank said. The letter came a day after Schneiderman announced that Bank of America and Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) violated terms of last year’s settlement with five banks that resolved claims over their foreclosure practices. The deal was negotiated with 49 states and the U.S. Schneiderman said he intended to sue the two lenders, claiming they “flagrantly violated” their obligations for processing mortgage modification applications from homeowners. Damien LaVera, a spokesman for Schneiderman, didn’t respond to a phone message or e-mail seeking comment on the letter. Lawrence Grayson, a spokesman for Charlotte, North Carolina-based Bank of America, declined to comment.
